loans.use: to purchase tools needed for her business and for working capital.

loans.name: Om

texts.en:
Om S., 29, owns a grocery shop where she sells many items including cooking ingredients, sweets, soft drinks, fast food, and other goods. She sells her products to passers-by and her neighbors. She has been running her grocery business for a few years and earns an average of $5 a day.

 To achieve financial stability for the whole family, her husband works as a domestic porter. The couple has only one young child who is still living under their care. Om S. wishes to expand her grocery business and is asking for a $500 loan to be used to purchase a larger amount of grocery items for selling. This loan will provide her and her family with extra income.

loans.use: To purchase a larger amount of grocery items to sell.

loans.name: Brenda

texts.en:
Brenda S. is from the village of Norte, Don Carlos, Bukidnon. She is 36 years old. Brenda is widowed and has 2 very young children. To make a living, Brenda owns & operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from buying and selling daily use products such as canned goods, snack foods & beverages in the local community. Brenda has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2011, Brenda joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Brenda is requesting a loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell like canned goods & snack foods. This will be the 1st loan taken out by Brenda from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell like canned goods & snack foods.

loans.name: Mrs. Mom Village Bank Group

texts.en:
This village bank loan consists of seventeen people who have selected Mrs. Mom to be the village bank president. All members will use their portion of the loan for varied ways to improve their family living.

Mrs. Mom weaves silk cloth to sell in order to earn some income to support her family. Since her business is getting on well, she wants to expand. Therefore, Mrs. Mom is asking for a loan to buy more silk for weaving. Her husband, Mr. Thy, owns a car which he uses for a taxi. She has eight children, one of wH. is a driver, another two are weavers, and the others are studying in local public school.

loans.use: to buy more silk

loans.name: Adelia

texts.en:
Adelia C. is from the village of Poblacion, Damulog, Bukidnon. She is 57 years old. Adelia is married and has 4 adult children. To make a living, Adelia owns & operates a specialized retail store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from buying and selling health & medicinal products such as generic drugs in the local community. Adelia has been engaged in her business for over one year and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2011, Adelia joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Adelia is requesting a loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell such as generic drugs. This will be the 1st loan taken out by Adelia from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional generic drugs, etc. to sell.

loans.name: Ly's Group

texts.en:
This group loan consists of six members who have selected Mrs. Ly to be the group leader. They will each use their portion of the loan for different purposes in order to improve their family's standard of living. 

Mrs. Ly is a farmer who owns a plot of land where she grows rice.  She sells part of the rice yield and uses the rest of the rice to support her family.  Her husband, Mr. Sou, is a construction worker. They work hard, but they earn little income. In order to improve their standard of living, Mrs. Ly is applying for a loan to add to her savings so that she can buy a cow to breeding and to start a new business. This couple has three children, one of whom is employed in a garment factory, but the others are students.

loans.use: to buy a cow

loans.name: Sá's Group

texts.en: Five people make up the group loan. Mrs. Sá was born in 1967, and she is the group leader. She was selected to be the group leader by the other members. She earns her living by selling sugar cane. Currently her sugar cane business has finished, because she doesn’t have any more sugar cane for selling. Thus in order to get more income from outside sugar cane, she would like to start a new business. So she decided to ask for a loan to buy thread and silk to weave and sell. Her husband, Mr. Phat, is a worker who is able to earn a small salary to support his family. This couple has four children who all are students and also help their mother with her businesses.

loans.use: To buy thread and silk.

loans.name: Chhin

texts.en:
Chhin A. is a local farmer who has been living in the city of Phnom Penh.  She can make a profit from this farming business of around $3 per day, and her husband also assists her in the same business. She always cultivates rice crops on her own farmland in both rainy season and dry season. 

Presently, she will plant her crop for the dry season rice field but she lacks some farming supplies. Chhin A. would like to request a loan to buy necessary farming supplies to start growing her crops. She hopes to use the rest of the loan funds to fix her broken machine. Chhin A. is blessed with three children, two of whom are single. One is married and lives independently.

loans.use: To buy necessary farming supplies and fix her broken machine.

loans.name: Josephine

texts.en:
Josephine B. is from the village of San Carlos, Valencia City, Bukidnon. She is 60 years old. Josephine is widowed and has 4 adult children. To make a living, Josephine owns & operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from buying and selling daily use products such as diapers, beverages, salt, noodles & coffee in the local community. Josephine has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 12,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Josephine joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Josephine has successfully repaid a previous loan of 14,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. Josephine is requesting a new loan of 16,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell like canned goods & snack foods. This will be the 4th loan taken out by Josephine from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell like canned goods & snack foods.

loans.name: He's Group

texts.en:
This village bank loan consists of fourteen members. Mrs. He, who was born in 1954, is the village bank president. She was selected to be the group leader by the other members. She is a farmer who owns a plot of land which she uses to grow both corn and peanuts for a living. Her husband, Mr. Nhoel, was born in 1952, works as a construction worker and is able to earn a small salary to help support his family.  Currently their house has become broken, and they want to fix it up. So in order to support this purpose, Mrs. He would like to ask for a loan to add to her savings and fix her house up. The rest of the loan she will use to build a porch.

This couple has a child who is seamstress in a garment factory.

loans.use: To add to her savings and fix her house up.

loans.name: Mrs. Sok Heang Village Bank Group

texts.en: Twelve people who make up a village bank loan will use their portion of the loan for different purposes but will overall improve their families' lives to a higher standard of living. Mrs. Sok Heang is a village bank president who has been selected by the other members. She and her husband, Mr. Pha Net, are mango sellers in the local market where they earn some income to support their family. Since her business is doing well, she wants to expand. So to improve this plan, Mrs. Sok Heang would like to ask for a loan to buy more mangoes for resale. Through this activity, she supports six children, two of whom are laborers, while the other two are studying in a local public school, and the others are too young to work or study.

loans.use: To buy more mangoes for resale

loans.name: Kum's Group

texts.en:
This group loan consists of four people. Mr. Kum was born in 1974, and is the group leader. He was selected to be the group leader by the other members. Each member of this group will use their portions of the loan to help support different purposes. 

Kum is a construction worker, while his wife, Mrs. Chhay is a seamstress in a garment factory. With their careers, they are able to earn some income that supports their family living. Currently, they want to build a kitchen, but they do not have enough money to support this purpose. Thus, Mr. Kum would like to ask for a loan to add to his saving and build a kitchen for cooking. This couple has three children who are all attending the local school.

loans.use: To build a kitchen for cooking.

loans.name: Ellen

texts.en:
Ellen A. is from the village of San Roque, Maramag, Bukidnon. She is 46 years old. Ellen is married and has four school-aged children. To make a living, Ellen owns & operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from buying and selling daily use products such as snack foods, canned goods, biscuits & detergents in the local community. Ellen has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 10,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Ellen joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Ellen has successfully repaid a previous loan of 11,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. Ellen is requesting a new loan of 14,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell like canned goods & snack foods. This will be the 4th loan taken out by Ellen from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HHSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell like canned goods & snack foods.

loans.name: Densmaa

texts.en:
Densmaa, is married and lives with her husband and a daughter in Gobi-Altai province of Mongolia. They live in a 'ger', a Mongolian nomadic housing tent, on a small plot of land that they have owned since 2007. Her husband is retired and her daughter helps her with the business. 

Densmaa began operating a cafe in 2000. She became a regular customer of XacBank when she got a loan of 300,000 MNT for her business in 2005. She supports her family's needs with her business income. She was able to help her children to start their own life by using her business revenues. She is a hardworking and open-minded person who says, "I want to expand my business and help my daughter to begin her own life." She is requesting a loan of 1,000,000 MNT to purchase more food ingredients for her cafe.

loans.use: To purchase more food ingredients.

loans.name: San's Group

texts.en:
There are four people who make up a group loan. Mrs. San was born in 1955, and is the group leader. She has been selected to be the group leader by the other members. The members of this group will use their portions of the loan to support their different purposes. 
San and her husband, Mr. Tes, are fishermen who are able to earn a small income to support their family living. With this business they face some problems, because they do not have enough money for fishing supplies. So in order to support the current business, San would like to ask for a loan to buy more fishing nets and fishing supplies. This couple has three children who are seamstresses at a garment factory.

loans.use: To buy more fishing nets and fishing supplies

loans.name: Laylyn

texts.en:
Laylyn B. is from the village of San Carlos, Valencia City, Bukidnon. She is 34 years old. Laylyn is married and has three school-aged children. To make a living, Laylyn owns & operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from buying and selling daily use products such canned goods, snack foods & milk in cans & boxes in the local community. Laylyn has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 10,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Laylyn joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Laylyn has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. Laylyn is requesting a new loan of 12,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell like snack foods & canned goods. This will be the 4th loan taken out by Laylyn from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell like snack foods & canned goods.

loans.name: San's Group

texts.en:
This group loan consists of five members. Mrs. San, who was born in 1955, is the group leader selected by the other members. She earns her living by selling meatballs in the local market. Since her business is doing well, she wants to expand it. She therefore decided to ask for a loan to buy more meatballs. 

Mrs. San's husband, who was born in 1957, works as a government worker and earns a small income to help support his family. This couple has three children: one is a motorbike taxi driver and the other two attend the local school.

loans.use: to buy more meatballs

loans.name: Tsogtbaatar

texts.en:
Tsogtbaatar, 40, is married and lives with his wife and three sons in Ulaanbaatar, the capital of Mongolia. They live in a house on a small plot of land that they own. His oldest son attends a college and their second son goes to a local secondary school while the youngest son goes to kindergarten. 

Tsogtbaatar lived in Japan for a few years and began making felt souvenirs and other items when he came back to Mongolia five years ago. He owns a building which he rents out for 400,000 MNT monthly to other business operators. His wife helps him to operate his business and that makes his business more family-based. They export their feltcraft items to Russia. 

Tsogtbaatar is a hardworking and initiative person who says, "I want to share with my community my business experience which I have gained so far in order make a contribution to the development of my country." He is requesting a loan of 3,000,000 MNT to purchase a stitching machine and materials for his feltcraft business.

loans.use: To purchase a stitching machine and materials

loans.name: Prom

texts.en:
Prom K., 34 years old, is a humble villager living in the capital of Cambodia, Phnom Penh. Prom K. is married and blessed with a young school-aged child, while her husband is a soldier in the province of Kompong Speu. 

To earn a living, Prom K. sells many kinds of products around her community such as soft drinks, food, cooking ingredients, perfume, plastic products, and some essential products. She is able to earn a profit of around $2.50 a day to help support the entire family. 

Recently, this family is not comfortable because their fence is getting old, and it often needs to be repaired. She also says that she really wants to build a new one, but her cash on hand is not enough. To solve this problem, Prom K. is asking for a loan to build a new fence.

loans.use: To build a new fence.

loans.name: Javzmaa

texts.en:
Javzmaa, 38, is married and lives with her husband and three children in Ulaanbaatar, the capital of Mongolia. Her husband works as a police officer, her two older sons attend a local secondary school while the youngest child goes to a kindergarten. 

She began selling children's clothing at Narantuul, the biggest outdoor market in Ulaanbaatar, in 2003. Then she expanded her business and started renting an additional stall at an indoor market. Now she operates her indoor stall by herself and has hired a salesperson for her stall in Naratuul. She is also renting a third stall in a bigger trading center and providing a workplace for her siblings. 

Her current working capital is 9,500,000 Mongolian tugriks (MNT). She is a hardworking and reliable person who says, "I am trying to expand my business as much as possible and save money in order to buy an apartment." 

She is requesting a loan of 3,000,000 MNT to purchase more clothing to sell at her newly rented stall.

loans.use: to purchase more clothing

loans.name: Theng's Group

texts.en: This group loan consists of four people who hope to increase their income to improve their families' lives. The  members have selected Mrs. Theng as group leader. She and her husband earn their living using their own car as a taxi. Mrs. Theng also earns her living by knitting and weaving. With all their businesses, this couple still earns a small income to support and improve their lives. In order to increase income to improve the family’s condition, Theng would like to ask for a loan to buy groceries to support her new grocery store business.  This couple has two children who attend a local school.

loans.use: to buy groceries

loans.name: Ulemj

texts.en: Ulemj, 52, is married and lives with his wife and two children in Ulaanbaatar, the capital of Mongolia. They live in a ger, a Mongolian nomadic housing tent, in someone's backyard. They have a decent standard of living. His wife is unemployed and operates a coal and firewood retail business. He began transporting goods using his own truck between Ulaanbaatar and western provinces in 1983. He currently owns a truck that can carry five tons of goods. He gets between 180-250 Mongolian tugriks (MNT) per kilo of goods when he transports them. Now he is planning to bring dairy products from the countryside and sell them in the city. He is a hardworking and sociable person who says, "I would like to carry on my transpiration business and make more profit." He is requesting a loan of 2,500,000 MNT to buy spare parts and to pay for the maintenance fees for his truck.

loans.use: to buy spare parts

loans.name: Jennyvi

texts.en: Jennyvi P. is from the village of Mibando, Quezon, Bukidnon. She is 33 years old. Jennyvi is married and has four school-aged children. To make a living, Jennyvi runs a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. The main source of income for the business comes from buying and selling daily-use products such as shampoo, soap, snack foods, canned goods and beverages in the local community. Jennyvi has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 5,000 Philippines pesos (PHP) a month from it. In 2010, Jennyvi joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Jennyvi has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. Jennyvi is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell such as canned goods and snack foods. This will be the second loan taken out by Jennyvi from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell such as canned goods and snack foods

loans.name: Mrs. Nat Village Bank Group

texts.en: This village bank loan consists of twelve people who will use their portions of the loan for different purposes to improve their families' living standards. Mrs. Nat is the village bank president selected by the members. Born in 1955, she is a widow with two children who attend a local public school. Mrs. Nat is a rice and Khmer cake seller in the local village, where she earns some money to supP. her family. She now wants to start a new business, but does not have enough money to do so. Therefore, Mrs. Nat is asking for a loan to buy a sugar cane juice machine to sell sugar cane juice.

loans.use: to buy a sugar cane juice machine

loans.name: Josefina

texts.en:
Josefina M. is from the village of Mibando, Quezon, Bukidnon. She is 31 years old. Josefina is married with three school-aged children. Josefina runs a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. The main source of income for the business comes from buying and selling daily use products such as canned goods, snack foods, candies and biscuits in the local community. Josefina has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month.

In 2010, Josefina joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services. Josefina has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional inventory and add to working capital. Josefina is requesting a new loan of 8000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell like canned goods and snack foods. This will be her second loan from HSPFI.

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell like canned goods and snack foods.

loans.name: Mrs. Phany Village Bank Group

texts.en: This village bank loan consists of twelve people who will use their portions of the loan in varied ways to improve their families' living standards. The members selected Mrs. Phany, who was born in 1971, as village bank president. She is a housewife who cooks delicious food for her family while her husband, Mr. Phally, is a construction worker. Mrs. Phany faces an obstacle because her stoves are too old to use. To improve this condition, Mrs. Phany is asking for a loan to build stoves. She is the mother of five children: two are seamstress in garment factories and the others attend a local public school.

loans.use: to build stoves

loans.name: Nhe's Group

texts.en:
This village bank loan consists of twenty-one members who will use their portions of the loan to support their different purposes. The members selected Mrs. Nhe as village bank president.

Nhe is a farmer who owns plot of land where she grows rice for a living. She is also a rice middleman, earning a small income to support her family. Since her business is going well, she wants to expand it. Thus, she decided to ask for a loan to buy more rice to enlarge her business. Nhe is a widow with a child who is also a rice middleman and who helps with Nhe's business.

loans.use: to buy more rice

loans.name: Marly

texts.en:
Marly L. is from the village of Mibando, Quezon, Bukidnon. She is 35 years old and married with three adult-aged children. Marly runs a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. The main source of income for the business comes from buying and selling daily-use products such as canned goods, snack foods and beverages in the local community. Marly has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month.

In 2010, Marly joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services. Marly has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional inventory and expand working capital. Marly is requesting a new loan of 8000 PHP to purchase additional products to sell like canned goods and snack foods. This will be her second loan from HSPFI.  

About HSPFI:

loans.name: San

texts.en: San S. is a humble mother who has been blessed with seven kids: six of them are single, and one is married and living in a separate house. Years ago San S. inherited a piece of farmland from her grandparents. She uses this land to grow a rice crop at least two times per year. She has received great success almost every year. Her husband also contributes to the household income by catching fish along the river in his village. Due to the lack of money, San S. decided to seek a loan to purchase farming materials such as fertilizer and gasoline for her farming business. She will use part of her loan to purchase nets and a boat for her husband's fishing business.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer, gasoline, and other supplies for her farming business, and nets and a boat for her husband.

loans.name: Mrs. Marann Village Bank Group

texts.en: This village bank loan consists of nine people will use their portions of the loan for different purposes to improve their families' living standards. The members have selected Mrs. Marann, who was born in 1964, as village bank president. She sells ice cream door-to-door to earn some money to support her family. Her husband, Mr. Net, is an iron welder who earns a small salary to support his family. This couple provides for two children: one is a car repairer and one attends a local public school. At present, Mrs. Marann's roof is leaking, so she needs some money to rebuild. She would like to ask for a loan to buy zinc to rebuild her roof.

loans.use: to buy zinc to rebuild her roof

loans.name: Mrs. Sophat Village Bank Group

texts.en: This village bank loan consists of fourteen members who have selected Mrs Sophat as village bank president. The members will use their portion of the loan for different purposes, such as improving their families' standard of living. Mrs Sophat was born in 1964. She mills rice for resale in order to support her family. Since her business is getting on well, she wants to expand. S. Mrs Sophat is applying for a loan to buy more rice to mill for resale. Her husband, Mr Art, is a motorcycle taxi driver. The couple has six children, three of whom are employed in garment factories, one is attending a local public school and the others are too young to work or study.

loans.use: to buy more rice to mill for resale.

loans.name: Ireen Joy

texts.en:
Ireen Joy B. is from the village of Mibando, Quezon, Bukidnon. She is 27 years old and married with two school-aged children. Ireen Joy runs a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. The main source of income for the business comes from buying and selling daily-use products such as shampoo, soap, canned goods, snack foods, biscuits and beverages in the local community. Ireen Joy has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately 6000 PHP a month.

In 2010, Ireen Joy joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services. Ireen Joy has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional inventory and expand working capital. Ireen Joy is requesting a new loan of 8000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell like canned goods and snack foods. This will be her second loan from HSPFI.

loans.name: Teofilo

texts.en:
Teofilo B. is from the village of Lurugan, Valencia City, Bukidnon. He is 52 years old. Teofilo is married with six school-aged children. Teofi runs a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. The main source of income for the business comes from buying and selling daily-use products such as shampoo, soap, canned goods, snack foods and beverages in the local community. Teofilo has been engaged in his business for over five years and earns approximately 10000 PHP a month.

This previous loan was used to to purchase additional inventory and expand working capital. loans.name: Yim

texts.en: Yim N. has been in farming for a long time. She lives in the province of Kompong Cham. Yim N. grows a rice crop, from which she earns a regular income. She is a 55-year-old widowed mother who has given birth to four children: one works in a garment factory as a seamstress and has a regular salary. In the past, Yim N. has always hired the neighbor’s cow to plow the farmland. Now she hopes to buy her own cow and that is why she is applying for a loan from Kiva.

loans.use: to buy a cow.

loans.name: Mrs. Nget Village Bank Group

texts.en: Fifteen people make up this village bank loan and they will use their portions of the loan for different purposes that can improve their families' standard of living. They have selected Mrs. Nget to be the village bank president. Mrs. Nget is a housewife who cooks delicious food for her family, so she has a lot of free time. In order to improve her family's income, Mrs. Nget would like to ask for a loan to buy some piglets for breeding to start a new business. She plans to use the rest of the loan to add to her savings so her family can buy a motorcycle in the future. Her husband, Mr. Houch, is a recycling salesman who earns some profit to support their family. Through these activities they support five children: two are employed in garment factories, one is a laborer and the other two are students.

loans.use: To buy some piglets for breeding

loans.name: Cheng's Group

texts.en:
This village bank loan consists of eleven members who will use their portions to support different purposes. Mrs. Cheng was selected to be the village bank president by the other members. 

Mrs. Cheng was born in 1964 and is a vegetable seller in the local market. She is able to earn a small amount of income to help support her family. Mrs. Cheng’s husband earns his living by driving a motorbike taxi. Currently her husband’s motorbike is old and she wants to replace it with a new one, so she would like to ask for a loan to increase her savings for a new motorbike for her husband's business. The couple has five children: four are students who help with their mother's business, and one is a monk.

loans.use: To increase her savings so she can soon purchase a new motorbike for her husband's transportation business

loans.name: Leonardo

texts.en:
Leonardo F. is from the village of Sta. Clara Aritao, Nueva Vizcaya. He is 44 years old. Leonardo is married with two school-aged children. Leonardo grows rice for sale. Leonardo has been engaged in his business for over 12 years and earns approximately 40000 PHP per harvest.

In 2011, Leonardo joined ASKI to gain access to financial services. Leonardo is requesting a new loan of 10000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizer such as manure. This loan will be his first from ASKI. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizer such as manure.

loans.name: Mary Rose

texts.en:
Mary Rose G. is from the village of Quezon San Isidro. She is 41 years old. Mary Rose is married with two school-aged children. Mary Rose runs a business selling cosmetics. Mary Rose has been engaged in her business for over one year and earns approximately 3500 PHP a month.

In 2010, Mary Rose joined ASKI to gain access to financial services. Mary Rose has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase materials needed to expand services she provides. Mary Rose is requesting a new loan of 7000 PHP which will also be used to purchase the materials needed to expand the services she provides. This will be her second loan from ASKI. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase materials needed to expand the services provided.

loans.name: Ly's Group

texts.en:
This village bank loan consists of eleven members who will use their portions to support different purposes. Mr. Ly was selected to be the village bank president by the other members. 

Mr. Ly was born in 1967. He and his wife are farmers who own a plot of land on which they grow different vegetables to earn a living. They don’t have enough money so Mr. Ly would like to ask for a loan to grow more crops. Aside from farming, they also sell sugar cane juice in the local village. With this business, they are able to earn a small amount of income to help support their family. The couple has three children who attend the local school.

loans.use: To grow more crops on their land

loans.name: Nhoem's Group

texts.en:
Fourteen people make up this village bank loan. Mrs. Nhoem was selected to be the village bank president by the other members. 

Mrs. Nhoem was born in 1965. She and her husband are farmers who own 2-hectare plot of land on which they grow both rice and lotus to make a living. In order to support this activity, Mrs. Nhoem would like to ask for a loan to buy fertilizer and pesticides for growing crops. Aside from farming, they also breed pigs and sell groceries at home. With both of these businesses, they are able to earn a small amount of income to support their family. The couple has two children: one works as a shoe garment worker and the other attends the local school.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and pesticides for growing crops

loans.name: Violeta

texts.en:
Violeta is a 61-year-old married woman who supports her family by operating three business ventures: a sari-sari store, food vending and raising livestock. 

Violeta lives in Negros Occidental with her family. She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 1996 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her businesses, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of PHP 40,000. 

Violeta is borrowing PHP 22,500 to purchase more stock to sell in her general store. This will be her 19th loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHP 19,500, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey toward economic freedom. Violeta aspires to elevate her family's living conditions and ensure their future wellbeing by following the Dungganon way.

loans.use: To purchase products for her store

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Leonida

texts.en:
Leonida works hard to support her only child. Leonida is married and has a food vending business in the Philippines. Leonida requested a loan of PHP 14,000 through NWTF to purchase raw materials. Leonida has been in this business for 10 years. The photo was taken after the center meeting and all food that she made was already sold out. 

In the future, Leonida would like to improve the way of living for her family.

loans.use: To purchase raw materials

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Ruth

texts.en:
Ruth works hard to support her six children. Ruth is a married woman and has a fish vending business in the Philippines.

Ruth requested a loan for PHP 18,000 through NWTF to increase the volume of fish that she sells. Ruth has been in this business for 17 years. Ruth also earns income from pig fattening. In the future, Ruth would like her children to earn college degrees.

loans.use: to purchase fish to resell

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Mekar Sandat Group

texts.en: Ni Made D. P. and all the members of the group are getting a second loan from MUK. Ni Made D. P. plans that the second loan will be used to buy four pigs. Ni Made D. P. works daily as a farmer and a housewife and has one child who is attending elementary school. This loan helps increase her pigs business.

loans.use: to buy four pigs

loans.name: Desederia

texts.en:
Desederia is a 49-year-old widow who supports her family by operating a general store. She lives in the island of Cebu. Desederia joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2009 because she aspired for something better for her family. 

With the help of her past three loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Desederia has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 9,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 6,000, uplifting the family's standard of living.  

This time, for her fourth loan, Desederia is borrowing PHP 10,000 to buy additional stocks for the general store so that she can continue to save up for the future education of her children. Desederia is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams.

loans.use: To purchase additional stock to sell

loans.name: Nhoem's Group

texts.en:
This village bank loan consists of seventeen members who will use their portions to support different purposes. Nhoem was selected to be the village bank president by the other members. 

Nhoem was born in 1945. His wife stays at home and cooks for the family. Nhoem is a farmer who owns a plot of land on which he grows rice and lotus to make a living. He faces a problem with money and would like to ask for a loan to buy fertilizers, pesticides and gasoline to support his crop growing. The couple has a child who also helps with the farming.

loans.use: To buy fertilizers, pesticides and gasoline to support his crop growing

loans.name: Nov

texts.en: From the province of Kompong Tom, Nov C., age 58, is a widowed woman and the mother of six children. Three of her children are now married and living separately, while the other three are single and employed. Nov sells food and cakes in her village. She is asking for a loan to buy wooden poles to mend her walls which are broken during the rainy season.

loans.use: to buy wooden poles to mend her walls.

loans.name: Gorgonia

texts.en: Gorgonia is a 41-year-old married woman who supports her family by operating a general store and a fish vending businesses.  She lives in Toledo, Cebu. She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2005 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her businesses, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of PHP 6,000. Gorgonia is borrowing PHP 12,000 to purchase more stock to sell.  This will be her 11th loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHP 13,000, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey toward economic freedom. Gorgonia aspires to elevate her family's living conditions and ensure their future wellbeing by following the Dungganon way.

loans.use: to purchase more stock to sell

loans.name: Oeung's Group

texts.en:
Fourteen people make up this village bank loan. Each member hopes to increase their income to improve their family's standard of living by using their portion of the loan. Mrs. Oeung, born in 1962, was selected to be the village bank president by the other members. 

Mrs. Oeung is a farmer who owns a plot of land on which she grows rice for a living. She doesn’t have enough money to sustain this business so she is requesting a loan to buy fertilizer and pesticide for growing rice in the dR. season. Mrs. Oeung’s husband is a fisherman who is able to earn a small amount of income to support their family, and he also helps his wife with farming. The couple has three children who attend the local school.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and pesticide for growing rice in the dry season

loans.name: Marvin

texts.en:
Marvin M. is from the village of Sta. Clara Aritao, Nueva Vizcaya. He is 26 years old. Marvin is married and has one infant-aged child. To make a living, Marvin owns & operates a business planting and harvesting rice to sell. Marvin has been engaged in his business for over five years and earns approximately 35,000 PHP every harvest season.

In 2011, Marvin joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Marvin is requesting a new loan of 15,000 PHP to purchase fertilizers such as manure. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Marvin from ASKI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand his business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers

loans.name: Yang's Group

texts.en:
This village bank loan consists of sixteen members who will use their portions to support different purposes. Mrs. Yang, born in 1963, has been selected to be the village bank president by the other members. 

Mrs. Yang’s husband is a motorcycle taxi driver who is able to earn a small amount of income to support their family. The couple doesn’t have any children. Mrs. Yang earns a living by selling both vegetables and fish in the local market. Since her business is doing well, she wants to expand it but does not have enough money to do so. Thus, she decided to ask for a loan to purchase more vegetables and fish for supporting and enlarging her business.

loans.use: To buy more vegetables and fish to expand her business

loans.name: Pum's Group

texts.en:
There are fifteen members who make up this village bank loan. Mr. Pum, a married man who was bO. in 1977, was selected to be the village bank president by the other members. They will use their portions of the loan to support different purposes. 

Mr. Pum is a construction worker. His wife, Mrs. Phai is a seamstress in a garment factory. With their careers they are able to earn a small salary to support their family. With both occupations, they still do not earn enough income to improve their standard of living. Thus, Mr. Pum would like to ask for a loan to purchase a cow for breeding. The couple has two children who attend the local schoO..

loans.use: To purchase a cow for breeding.

loans.name: Sor's Group

texts.en:
This village loan consists of eleven members who will use their portions to support different purposes. Mrs. Sor, a married woman who was born in 1980, was selected to be the village bank president by the other members. 

Mrs. Sor earns a living by selling groceries in the local village. Since her business is doing well, she wants to expand it. Thus, she decided to ask for a loan to buy more groceries to support and enlarge her business. Her husband, Mr. Pin, was born in 1979 and works as a house constructor. He is also able to earn a small amount of income to support their family. The couple has two children who attend the local school.

loans.use: To buy more groceries to expand her business

loans.name: Sarann

texts.en: Mrs. Sarann was born in 1988 and is married to Mr. Makara. They are farmers who own a small plot of land on which they cultivate rice. They sell part of the rice yield and use the other part to sustain their family. Mr. Makara is also a palm juice collector and a firewood salesman. In order to improve their family's income, they want to start a new business but do not have the money to do so. Thus, Mrs. Sarann is requesting a loan to buy a cow for breeding. The couple supports a child who is 1 year old.

loans.use: To purchase a cow for breeding

loans.name: Edgard

texts.en:
Edgard G. is from the village of Olango. He is 44 years old. Edgard is married and has five school-aged children. To make a living, Edgard owns & operates a business planting and harvesting rice to sell. Edgard has been engaged in his business for over 11 years and earns approximately 35,000 PHP every cropping season.

In 2011, Edgard joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Edgard is requesting a new loan of 27,000 PHP to purchase fertilizers such as manure. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Edgard from ASKI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay the tuition fees of his children. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers

loans.name: Kembang Kertas Group

texts.en:
The group is located at Pangkung Lip Lip Sub-State. The head of the group, Ni Nengah S., is 33 years old. All 10 members of the group are getting their second loans for a total of Rp. 15,000,000.

The loan is expected to increase her business capital so she can buy two pigs. With the first loan, she has managed to obtain an average profit of Rp. 200,000 to Rp. 250,000.  Her profits were used to supplement her daily needs and to increase school fees. On the date when the loan was disbursed, a member named Ni Ketut S. did not attend because of illness. They hope that in the future this cooperation continues to be ongoing. If possible, they would like to have the loan amount increased and the period extended.

loans.use: to buy two pigs

loans.name: Bora

texts.en: Mrs Bora was born in 1982 and is married to Mr Koem Oun, who is 31 years old. The couple are chicken breeders and farmers who own a 1.2-hectare plot of land where they cultivate rice. They sell some of the rice and consume the rest. Mr Koem Oun also cuts firewood to sell. Although they work a lot they can only earn a little income. In order to improve their situation, Mrs Bora is asking for a loan to buy five piglets and pig food to start a new business, pig breeding. She will use the rest of the loan to buy more chickens. The couple supports two children who are too young to work or study.

loans.use: to buy five piglets and pig food.

loans.name: Touch's Group

texts.en:
This group loan consists of five members, each of whom will use their portion of the loan for different purposes. Mrs. Touch was chosen by the members T. be the group's leader.

Touch, who was born in 1977, earns her living by vending soup and balut eggs in the local village. In order T. increase income T. improve the family’s condition, she is requesting a loan T. buy more soup supplies and more balut eggs T. support and enlarge her business activities. Her husband, born in 1975, works as a construction worker and is able T. earn a small salaR. T. support the family. This couple has three children who attend the local school.

loans.use: to buy more soup supplies and more balut eggs to support and enlarge her business activities.

loans.name: Ra

texts.en: Mrs. Ra is 24 years old and a farmer who owns a 1.5-hectare plot of land where she grows rice, some of which she sells to support her family. Her husband, Mr. Phor, works in a in garment factory where he makes a small salary to support his family. Mrs. Ra's house is far away from her husband’s work place so she is asking for a loan to buy a new motorcycle for transportation. She is the mother of a one-year-old child.

loans.use: To buy a new motorcycle

loans.name: Juliet

texts.en:
Juliet S. is from the village of Buenavista, Bayombong, Nueva Vizcaya. She is 40 years old. Juliet is married and has four school-aged children. To make a living, Juliet owns and operates a specialized retail store, selling rice in their local community. She has been engaged in her business for over three  years and earns approximately $238 a month for these activities.

In 2011, Juliet joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a loan of 20,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This will be her 1st loan from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful micro-finance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to invest in more rice to sell to expand her business.

loans.name: Nhy

texts.en: Mrs.Nhy, born in 1959, owns a general store in her local village where she sells groceries to support her family. Her husband, Mr. Oeun, is a farmer who owns a four-hectare plot of land where he grows rice to sell and for his family to eat. He has a lot of free time so Mrs. Nhy is asking for a loan to buy a cow to start a new cow-breeding business. This couple has two children, one of whom is a construction worker, and the other is studying in the local public school.

loans.use: To buy a cow

loans.name: Mom's Group

texts.en: Mrs. Mom is the leader of this five-member group loan; they will all use their portions of the loan for different purposes to improve their families' standard of living. She was born in 1982 and is a farmer who owns 2.5-hectare plot of land where she can grow rice both to sell and to feed her family. Her husband, Mr. Korb, is a taxi driver who earns some money to support his family. He wants to start a new business so Mrs. Mom is asking for a loan to buy an iron welding machine for her husband. She has three children, one of whom is enrolled in local public school, while the others are too young to work or study.

loans.use: To buy an iron welding machine

loans.name: Chea's Group

texts.en: Mrs. Chea, born in 1950, is the leader of this group, selected by the other members. Each member of the group will use her portion of the loan for a different purpose. Chea and her husband, Mr. Moeun, are wedding chefs who earn a small income to support their family. They also grow cucumbers, herbs, and spring onions to make more profit. They want to buy a motorcycle for transportation, but do not have enough money to purchase it so Mrs. Chea would like to ask for a loan to add to her savings to purchase a motorcycle for transportation. This couple has six children: three are seamstresses in the garment factory, two are students, and the last one is a wedding chef. Mrs. Sok is a group guarantor, and she is also in this picture.

loans.use: To add to her saving to purchase a motorcycle for transportation.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy a new ox to replace the old one.

loans.name: Aom's Group

texts.en: This group has four members. Mrs Aom was selected to be the group leader by the other members. The members of this group will use their portions of the loan for different purposes. Aom is a farmer who owns a plot of land that she uses to cultivate lotus for a living. She would like to ask for a loan to help her in growing lotus. Aom was born in 1957 and she is widow with six children: two are laborers, one is a seamstress in a garment factory and the others are students and also help their mother farming.

loans.use: to grow lotus.

loans.name: Tohirchon

texts.ru: Детканов Тохирчон проживает в городе Турсунзаде. Возраст, 35 лет. Женат. У него четверо детей. Жена, домохозяйка. Сам Тохирчон занимается растениеводством. Он в основном выращивает овощи для продажи. В этой области имеет богатый опыт. Кредит берет для закупа семян и минеральных удобрений.
texts.en: Tohirchon D. lives in the town of Tursun-zoda. He is 35 years old, married and has four children. His wife is a homemaker. Tohirchon does agriculture. He mainly grows vegetables for resale and has a rich experience in this business. He is taking out the loan to buy seeds and mineral fertilizer.

loans.use: to buy seeds and mineral fertilizer

loans.name: Fiapito

texts.en:
Age:                            33
Marital Status:             Married
Children:                      3
Business:                    providing shirt making services to local community members
Loan purpose:              to purchase additional fabrics and materials
Weekly profit:              350 WST   ($146)

Overall Social Metric Score:*               2 out of 3
Level of Education:                             1.9 out of 3
Level of total Household Income:         1.9 out of 3
Quality of Household Assets:              2 out of 3

Fiapito owns and operates a business venture, providing shirt-making services to local community members.  She has two years of experience in this business.    

Fiapito needs a loan of 1500 WST to purchase additional fabrics and supplies.  She plans to use the profit from her business (estimated to be 350 WST or about $146 per week) to pay for her children's tuition fees.

In 2009, Fiapito joined SPBD to gain access to financial services.  Most of SPBD's clients are unable to borrow from commercial banks because they lack collateral.  This is Fiapito's 2nd loan with SPBD. 



*SPBD evaluates the living conditions of each of its borrowers.  Generally, a loan manager evaluates a variety of social metrics on a scale out of 3 (the higher the number, the better off the person is) and these are averaged for the ""overall social metric score.""  For example, a 3 out of 3 on ""level of education"" would mean that the borrower has graduated from university.  

About  SPBD 
In 2000, Greg Casagrande founded SPBD to improve the quality of life of people living in poverty in the poor island nations of the South Pacific.  SPBD's philosophy of lending is based on a respect for each individual's innate human ingenuity, drive and self esteem. Please join SPBD's lending team on KIVA to receive on-the-spot updates on SPBD.  "

loans.use: to purchase additional fabrics and supplies

In 2011, Kalala joined SPBD to gain access to financial services. Most of SPBD's clients are unable to borrow from commercial banks because they lack collateral.  This is Kalala's 1st loan with SPBD.

Generally, a loan manager evaluates a variety of social metrics on a scale out of 3 (the higher the number, the better off the person is) and these are averaged for the ""overall social metric score."" Children:                      3

She needs a loan of 1,000 WST to purchase raw ingredients needed to make the products she sells.  She plans to use the profits (estimated to be 250 WST or around $104 per week) to expand her business.

loans.name: Esperanza

texts.en:
Esperanza S. is from the village of Puerta, Lurugan, Valencia City, Bukidnon. She is 59 years old. Esperanza is married and has one adult-aged child. To make a living, she owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop, selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap, canned goods, snack foods, noodles and beverages in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately $125 a month for these activities.

In 2011, Esperanza joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell like canned goods and biscuits. This will be her 1st loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell like canned goods & biscuits

loans.name: Ban

texts.en: Ban N. was born in 1958. She is a married woman and blessed with six children. Two of her children are single and four are married and live in their own houses. Her husband is Svay Mey, who is 66 years old. He makes a living by cultivating rice crops. To earn a living, Ban N. sells rice soup and Khmer noodle in and around her community, in Kompong Chhnang province. The house of one of her children is in the process of being built, but they need money to buy roofing tiles. Ban N. would like to ask for a loan to buy roofing tiles for her child's house.

loans.use: to purchase roofing tiles for her child's house.

loans.name: Khushrumo

texts.ru: Сапарова Хушрумо проживает в районе Яван. Возраст, 41 год. Замужем, имеет 4 детей. Муж занимается строительными работами по найму. Сама Хушрумо занимается животноводством. Она разводит крупнорогатый скот в дальнейшем для продажи. Этим видом деятельности занимается уже год. Кредит берет для закупа дойной коровы, чтобы увеличить количество скот и обеспечить семью молоком.
texts.en: Khushrumo S. lives in the region of Yavan. She is 41 years old. She is married and has four children. Her husband does freelance construction work. Khushrumo does animal husbandry. She breeds large cattle for future resale. She has been doing this business for one year. She is taking out the loan to buy one milk cow to increase cattle headcount and provide the family with milk.

loans.use: to buy a milk cow

loans.name: Jennyfe

texts.en:
Jennyfe T. is from the village of Pag-asa, Salawagan, Quezon, Bukidnon. She is 33 years old. Jennyfe is married and has one school-aged child. To make a living, she owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop, selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap, canned goods, snack foods and beverages in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately $75  a month for these activities.

In 2007, Jennyfe joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. 

Jennyfe is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell like canned goods and beverages. This will be her 4th loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell like canned goods and beverages.

loans.name: Gloria's Group

texts.en:
Gloria lives in Khanewal, which is a small city of Pakistan known for its agriculture industry. She has been living there in a two-room brick house with her family in the area of Shanti nagar for the past twenty-four years. She is 44 years of age and has three children, two daughters and a son. Her son left his education after intermediate level and started working to financially contribute to the family. Her daughters are enrolled in a local school and getting their education. 

Gloria shares the financial burden with her husband by doing sewing work. She is very skillful in her work and receives regular orders every month. She has applied for a loan from the Kiva partner, Asasah, for the improvement of her sewing business. She will use the loan in buying a new sewing machine that will help her complete her work more quickly and make more income. She has been doing this business for the past five years and is hopeful that an investment will bring more money and she will be able to provide better living facilities to her family. 

She is a regular loan user of Asasah and this is her 3rd loan application. In previous loan years, she has proved herself as a responsible client by paying her installments on time and attending every meeting. 

Note: In the photo, the lady holding a book (called Asasah Passbook) is Gloria.

loans.use: to buy a new sewing machine.

loans.name: Marilou

texts.en:
Marilou M. is from the village of Poblacion, Valencia City, Bukidnon. She is 32 years old and married. To make a living, she owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop, selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap, canned goods, junk foods, biscuits and beverages in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately $250 a month for these activities.

In 2010, Marilou joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. 

Marilou is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell like canned goods and beverages. This will be her 2nd loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell like canned goods and beverages.

loans.name: Sergei

texts.en:
Sergei is married with one three-year old son. He runs a small business raising vegetables in greenhouses. Sergei has been in this business for four years. He enjoys it very much and wants to develop it further.

Last year Sergei got a micro loan and used it to build the second greenhouse. This year he wants to make heating in greenhouses to allow him to harvest earlier and make better sales. Next year Sergei would like to build a third greenhouse to increase his sales and make better living for his family. Sergei is requesting 12,000 UAH to purchase a heating system.

loans.use: to purchase heating system

loans.name: Teofila

texts.en: Teofila is a married woman who lives in Narra, Palawan. She earns her living by operating wood lamination and food vending businesses. Her husband Lemuel, who is 39 years old, works as a vendor to earn his living and helps in his wife's business activities.  They have three children who are between 5 and 12 years old. Teofila joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2008 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her first loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Teofila has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 8,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 8,000, uplifting the family's standard of living.  This time, for her second  loan, she is borrowing PHP 10,000 to buy raw materials for wood lamination so that she can continue to save up for the future education of her children and expansion of business. Teofila is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams.

loans.use: to purchase raw materials for wood lamination

loans.name: Letecia

texts.en:
Letecia M. is from the village of Poblacion, Valencia City, Bukidnon. She is 43 years old. Letecia is married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, she owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop, selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap, canned goods, snack foods and beverages in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately $125 a month for these activities.

In 2010, Letecia joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. 

Letecia is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell like canned goods and snack foods. This will be her 2nd loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell like canned goods and snack foods.

loans.name: Gloren

texts.en:
Gloren S. is from the village of Balila, Lantapan, Bukidnon.  She is 31 years old.  Gloren is married.  To make a living, Gloren owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop.  While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from buying and selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap, canned goods, junk foods & beverages in the local community.  Gloren has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 8,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Gloren joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities.  Gloren has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI.  This previous loan was used to to purchase additional inventory and working capital.  Gloren is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell like canned goods and beverages.  This loan will be the 2nd loan taken out by Gloren from HSPFI.  She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell like canned goods and beverages

loans.name: Amerta Kencana Group

texts.en:
Ni Putu S. is the leader of the group Amerta Kencana. Ni Putu S. has two children. The first daughter is still in elementary school and the second child is three years old. As a creative housewife, Ni Putu S. always workhard to support her family income. She has been engaged in the pig business since she married I Ketut Sernen.

To promote her livestock business, Ni Putu S. applied for a loan from MUK. The loan used to buy four piglets that will be maintained for about 4-5 months and then sold. The profits from their pigs will be used for the purpose of supporting the family economy.

loans.use: To buy four piglets

loans.name: Freddie Salvador's Group

texts.en:
Freddie S. is from the village of Sun Life, Naguilan, Ilagan, Isabela. He is 44 years old. Freddie is the group leader of a six-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Freddie S.'s Group.

Freddie is married and has three school-aged children. To make a living, he owns and operates a business venture in the retail sector selling home products. The main source of income for the business comes from selling personal home products to tourists and local community members. Freddie has been engaged in his business for over three years and earns approximately $93 a month for these activities.

In 2010, Freddie joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. He has successfully repaid a previous loan of 4,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase raw materials needed to make products for sale. 

Freddie is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be his 2nd loan from ASKI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated to expand his business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful micro-finance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional home products to sell.

loans.name: Noreen's Group

texts.en:
Noreen lives in Khanewal which is a small city located in Punjab, Pakistan, and is known for its agriculture industry. She has been living there in the area of Shanti nagar with her family in a two-room brick house for the past sixteen years. She is married to K. who is involved in the agriculture profession. He works a small piece of land and grows different seasonal crops on it and sells to his customers. He has been in this profession for the past ten years and has vast knowledge about this work.
 
Noreen is the mother of three children. Only one of them is able to attend school and is getting his education. She has applied for a loan from the Kiva partner, Asasah, for her husband’s business. With the loan, he will buy fertilizers and seeds to grow crops and to get maximum output from his field.  
Noreen is hopeful that an investment will put her husband’s business in a more profitable position and her family will be able to enjoy better financial benefits as a result. 

She is a regular loan user of Asasah and this is her 3rd loan application. In previous loan years, she has always paid her installments on time and never missed a single meeting. 

Note: In the photo, the lady holding a book (called Asasah Passbook) is Noreen.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer and seeds to grow crops.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase additional inventory for her cell phone shop.

loans.name: Ashawanja

texts.en:
Ashawanja L. is a 55-year-old married lady with three children. She has been selling charcoal in Mbutu Kusema area in Malindi town for the past four years. The business allows her earn a monthly income of about 2,000 KES. 

Ashawanja has been loaned 60,000 KES by KADET LIMITED; this is her third loan cycle from the company. She intends to use half of her loan to sustain and grow her business by buying more sacks of charcoal to serve as her business stock. The rest of the money will be used to put up a permanent structure made of building blocks and cement for her business. 

In the future, she hopes to use the anticipated profits from her occupation to finish building her two rental houses so that she will be in a good position to earn revenue from them when she retires from her charcoal business.

loans.use: To buy more charcoal and to build a structure for her charcoal business

loans.name: Shameem's Group

texts.en:
Shameem is a very helpful lady, Along with her household responsibilities, she also helps her husband in his agriculture business. She is married to S., who works in the fields. He grows different seasonal crops, and after cultivating the crops he sells them to his customers. He is very experienced in his work and has many business contacts. 

She has applied for a loan from the Kiva partner, Asasah, to improve her husband’s business. With the loan, he will buy seeds and fertilizers for his fields to gain good results.  She is a regular loan user of Asasah and this is her 2nd loan application. She established a good credit record in the previous year by paying her installments on time. 

Shameem belongs to a small city of Pakistan called Khanewal. It is known for its agriculture industry. She has been living there in the area called Shanti nagar in a two-room brick house with her family for the past fifteen years. She has a son and a daughter. Her son has a job in the private sector, and her daughter is studying in college.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and seeds for the farm

loans.name: Isabelita

texts.en:
Isabelita G. is from the village of Bayabo 2, Tumauini, Isabela. She is 40 years old. Isabelita is married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, she owns and operates a general store, selling a variety of different products in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over ten years and earns approximately 5000 Php a month for these activities.

In 2007, Isabelita joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities.
