She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 15,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional canned goods, noodles, soft drinks and rice to sell. 

Isabelita is requesting a new loan of 15,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be her 8th loan from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful micro-finance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional canned goods, noodles, soft drinks and rice to sell

loans.name: Asha

texts.en:
Asha L. is a 37-year-old married lady with four children, all below the age of 18. Asha has been operating a local hotel for the residents of the Barani area in Malindi, Kenya, for the past four years. The business enables her to earn a monthly income of about 6000 Kenyan shillings (KES), which she uses to provide for her family’s needs, such as educating her children. 

Asha requested a loan of 20,000 KES from KADET. This is her third loan from the organization. She intends to use the loan to purchase more serving plates, water jugs, tea cups, tea spoons, and benches for her ever-growing clientele.

In the future, Asha hopes to use the profits from her business to sustain and grow her hotel and to open up a charcoal business near the hotel with a view toward making more money from the two businesses and thereby being able to improve her family’s standard of living.

loans.use: to purchase dishware and benches

loans.name: Caleb Mang'ang'a

texts.en:
Caleb, 26 years old, has been selling basins, wall hangings and frames in Naivasha town for the last 5 years.   His business is in an open area and he is therefore able to attract many customers who are passing by.

He was introduced to KADET by his friend and this will be his fourth loan.  He repaid all his previous loans well and in good time.  He plans to use the loan to buy more retail items for sale in his business area. He anticipates good returns from this investment.

In future, Caleb hopes to move to a more permanent place to operate his business from.

loans.use: To buy more retail items for sale.

loans.name: Marivic

texts.en:
Marivic M. is from the village of Poblacion North, Nueva Vizcaya. She is 36 years old. Marivic is married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, Marivic owns and operates a welding shop. She has been engaged in her business for more than 20 years and earns approximately 7000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Marivic joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Marivic has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. Marivic is requesting a new loan of 8000 PHP, which will be used to purchase materials needed to expand services provided. This loan will be the third loan taken out by Marivic from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About ASKI:
ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fishers, and small-business entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase welding materials

loans.name: Komilahon's Group

texts.ru:
Комилахон Вахидова, 28, лидер этой группы, молодая мама троих детей и к тому же уже больше десятка лет вовлечена в бизнес разведения и продажи скота. На данный момент ее домашнее хозяйство состоит из одной коровы и 4 кур. Птицеводством Комилахон решила заниматься сравнительно недавно. Оно приносит небольшие доходы , но все же помогает покрывать кое-какие расходы. Супруг, так же как и старший сын работает в частном строительстве. Бизнес  приносит 2 000 сомов прибыли в месяц. Немного, но Комилахон сумела скопить маленькую сумму для постройки нового коровника. Когда она узнала, что нужно собрать группу единомышленников, Комилахон ни на минуту не сомневалась кто будет членами ее группы. Она очень сильно хочет закупить больше мелко рогатого скота для откорма и разведения, также как и остальные члены группы, планирующие потратить кредит на развитие бизнеса. 

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 
								
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.
texts.en:
Komilahon V. is 28 years old. She is a leader of this group and is a young mother of three children. Besides that she has been involved in business of breeding and selling cattle for more then a decade.

At this time there are one cow and four chickens in her household. Relatively recently Komilahon decided to start breeding poultry. It brings her a small income, but still helps to cover some expenses. Her husband as well as her oldest son works in private construction business. It brings 2000 soms of income a month. Not very much, but Komilahon was able to save a small amount to build a new cow house. When she found out that she needs to bring together a group of like minded people Komilahon has not for a minute doubted who will be the members of her group.

She very much wants to buy more of small horned cattle for feeding and growing, as well as other members of the group who plan to spend the loan on developing their businesses.

loans.use: to buy small horned cattle

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase metallic materials and machines

loans.name: Raatkan's Group

texts.ru:
Рааткан Батаева, 65, лидер этой группы. Жительница города Узген Ошской области Рааткан можно отнести к тем женщинам, силой которых не перестаешь удивляться. Рааткан –мать героиня. Родив и воспитав семерых детей, к несчастью недавно она осталась вдовой. К счастью дети Рааткан уже взрослые и поддерживают ее в моральном и материальном плане. 42 года назад выйдя замуж Рааткан  вложила 2 000 сомов в закупку пары голов мелко рогатого скота. С тех пор она – частый посетитель скотного рынка Жазы, где она продает бережно откормленный месяцами скот. Младшие сыновья Алым и Асан частенько помогают матери. За все эти годы Рааткан справила пышную свадьбу своих сыновей. Также она совмещает земледелие с основным занятием. Ей нужно поторопиться приобрести удобрения так как посевной сезон уже у порога. Рааткан очень надеется, что этот кредит позволит ей купить одну тонну удобрений. 

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 
								
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.
texts.en:
Raatkan B. is 65 years old, she is a leader of this group. She is a resident of the town of Uzgen of the Osh province. Raatkan can be considered ones of those women who do not cease to surprise. Raatkan is a heroic mother. She birthed and raised seven children, but to her misfortune she became a widow just recently. Luckily her children are now grown up and support Raatkan emotionally and financially.

Raatkan has invested 2000 soms in the purchase of two heads of cattle when she got married 42 years ago. Since then she has been a frequent visitor to the Zhazi cattle market where she sells cattle which has been fed lovingly for several months. Youngest sons, Alym and Asan, often help their mother. During the past years Raatkan has held very festive weddings for her sons.

She also combines agriculture with animal husbandry. She needs to hurry and purchase fertilizer because the sowing season is quickly approaching. Raatkan is very hopeful that this loan will allow her buy one ton of fertilizer.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer for the sowing

loans.name: Cyrus Tepela

texts.en:
Cyrus has practised farming in Naivasha town for the last 10 years and gets good returns from this business. He is 24 years old and married to Janet N..  

He was introduced to KADET by his friend and this will be his first loan.  He plans to use the loan amount to buy seedlings and fertilizer.

In future, Cyrus hopes to buy a pick-up truck which he will be using to transfer his farm products to the market.

loans.use: To buy seedlings and fertilizer.

loans.name: Isaac

texts.en: Isaac K. is 30 years old and lives in the town of Tororo, in the Mbale region of Uganda.  He is married and has one child who is not in school.  Isaac has a stationary shop, which he has had for less than one year. To help expand his business, Isaac has requested a loan of 2,000,000 Ugandan shillings from BRAC Uganda.  The loan will be used to purchase more photocopy paper and exercise books for resale.  With the help of this loan from BRAC, Isaac hopes to generate greater profit and buy food.  In the future, Isaac hopes to expand his business.

loans.use: to purchase more photocopy paper and exercise books for resale

loans.name: Regina Njeri

texts.en:
Regina has been distributing water in Naivasha town for the last 7 years.  She is 32 years old, married to Atanasio Muriuki and they have one child.  

She was introduced to KADET by her friend and this will be her first loan.  She plans to use the loan amount to buy another cart for distributing water as the demand is very high and sometimes she is not able to meet her customer needs.

In future, Regina hopes to diversify her sources of income and open a retail shop.

loans.use: To buy another cart for distributing water.

loans.name: Daniel

texts.en:
Daniel M., whose wife takes care of the household chores, is the father of two children, 19 and 8 years of age; Daniel and his wife hope to give both a quality education to the university level. They in Mombasa, Kenya, the coastal region of Kenya well-known for its many tourist attraction sites including the Indian Ocean's white beaches.

For the past two-and-a-half years Daniel has owned a general store located at Jomvu estate selling such items as rice, flour, oil, detergents, soft drinks, etc. to the local people. While the business is profitable, financial constraints are Daniel's biggest challenge. However, he works very hard to maintain the health of his enterprise, and will use his loan of Kes 50,000 to buy more general items to expand it. Describing himself as very aggressive, Daniel hopes to be a wholesaler in the future.

loans.use: to purchase sugar, flour, detergents, and beverages

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase a photocopier machine.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to add new items to her stock of produce for sale

loans.name: Sayorai

texts.ru: Сайёраи Махмадамини проживает в районе Яван. Ей 21 год. Она замужем, имеет двоих детей. У нее среднее образование. Она занимается животноводством.  Разводит скот у себя дома. Она в основном разводит скот в дальнейшем для продажи. Этим видом деятельности занимаетcя 3 года. Целью кредита является покупка бычка.
texts.en: Sayorai M. lives in the Yavan region. She is 21 years old. She is married and has two children. She has secondary education. She does animal husbandry and breeds cattle at home. Sayorai mainly breeds the cattle for resale and has been in this business for three years. The purpose of her loan is to buy a calf.

loans.use: to buy a calf

loans.name: Edwina

texts.en:
Edwina aged 38 years is a single mother of two children, Mina aged 13 years and Rina aged 10 years who are both in primary school. She runs a boutique which is located in Kitengela town where most of her clients are female. Her business of 6 years gives her a monthly profit of Kshs.50, 000.

Edwina was introduced to KADET by a customer. This is her fourth loan and she intends to use it to open another boutique shop in Mlolongo. The profits from this business  will be used in the education of her children.

loans.use: To open another boutique shop in Mlolongo.

loans.name: Peter  Onyango

texts.en:
Peter is twenty eight years old and single. He runs a photo studio as a primary business and at the same time does laundry services in Gomongo Thika.

Peter is servicing his first loan from KADET LTD. He will use the entire loan amount to purchase a new camera.

Peter will use the anticipated profit to boost his business and also improve his living standards.He hopes to settle down and have a family,and  expand his business.

loans.use: To purchase a new camera.

loans.name: Born

texts.en:
Born T., age 36, is married to Saran, age 36. They have three children, all of whom are attending school. 

To earn a living, Born T. grows rice crops on his farmland. On average, he makes a profit of about $1.40 per day. His wife also works in the farming business. 

With this loan, Born T. will purchase a plot of farmland from a villager in order to grow more and various kinds of crops. This will enable the family to accrue an extra profit to meet their daily expenses.

loans.use: to purchase a plot of farmland

loans.name: Jocelyn

texts.en:
Jocelyn M. is from the village of Bayabo, Tumuini, Isabela. She is 40 years old. Jocelyn is married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, Jocelyn raises livestock, primarily ducks, for sale. Jocelyn has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 8,000 PHP.

In 2007, Jocelyn joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her business and living situation. Jocelyn has successfully repaid a previous loan of 15,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase baby livestock to raise and sell in the future. 

Jocelyn is requesting a new loan of 25,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase livestock feed and other supplies. This will be the eighth loan taken out by Jocelyn from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the loan to improve/expand the borrower's business. 

About ASKI:
ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase livestock feed and other supplies

loans.name: Munkhtuya

texts.en:
Munkhtuya N. is 30 years old and lives with her husband and two children in Ulaanbaatar, the capital of Mongolia. They all live together in a ger, the traditional Mongolian housing tent, on their plot of land. 

She operates a carpentry business with her husband in their home. She produces a variety of wooden furniture products including chairs, tables, sofas and wardrobes. And also she operates a retail business and purchases furniture from Ereen, the Chinese border city, and resells it for a profit.  

Munkhtuya rents a stall at the Narantuul market, the biggest outdoor market in Ulaanbaatar. She has gained valuable experience in the previous year and has a loyal customer base. Munkhtuya has been planning to expand their product line and increase their sales and to give a good education her children and teach them morals. 

She is requesting a loan to pay her stall rent and increase her business capital.

loans.use: to pay the rent on her market stall and expand production

loans.name: Nicodemus

texts.en:
Nicodemus M. aged 33 years is married with three children; Shirley, Britney and Ann. He runs a shop located at Njiru market which is a busy market. He has been running this business for 5 years and it gives him a monthly profit of Kshs.5, 000.

He was introduced to KADET by an existing client. This loan of Kshs.80, 000 is his fourth loan with Kadet and he plans to use it to add stock of sugar, soda, cooking oil, salt and sweets. The profits expected will be used to educate his children and improve the living standards of his family.

Nicodemus’ dreams and hopes are to turn his shop into a supermarket. He describes himself as hardworking.

loans.use: To add stock of sugar, soda, cooking oil, salt and sweets.

loans.name: Ghwar

texts.en:
Ghwar is a 47-year-old married man living in Chtoura with his wife and five children. 

Ghwar has worked in agriculture since 2005. He plants fruits and vegetables depending on what's suitable for the season. He works hard to raise his plants in a clean and healthy atmosphere. He tests the soil from time to time to see its quality. 

Ghwar is well known in the market. Most of his clients are wholesale businessmen, in addition to a few friends, neighbors and relatives. Most of the dealers wait for his products.

Ghwar is requesting a loan from A. Majmoua in order to buy necessary seeds to plant. This is his first loan, and he hopes to have positive results. He hopes to expand his business and buy his own land.

loans.use: to buy seeds

loans.name: Porn

texts.en: Porn Y. has been spending her life cultivating crops. This is a skill she learned from her grandparent when she was young. She is now married and has five kids. None of them are employed yet. Her husband works in the farm fields frequently alongside her. Growing crops is an annual activity with which she has had great success. She can plant crops at least twice a year by following both rainy and dry seasons. She planted her crops over two months ago but they are not growing well because of lack of fertilizers. To solve this problem, Porn Y. is asking for a Kiva loan to buy many sacks of fertilizer so her crops will grow well. Porn Y. and her husband are in the picture.

loans.use: to buy many sacks of fertilizer so her crops will grow well.

loans.name: Naseem's Group

texts.en:
Naseem is 36 years old and married to H.. She has 4 children, all of whom are enrolled in a local school and getting their education. Naseem knows the importance of education and wants her children to become successful in their lives by completing their education. Naseem belongs to a small city located in the Punjab province of Pakistan called Khanewal. Her house consists of 2 rooms and is located in the area of Shanti nagar. Naseem operates an animal-sales business at her home. She buys young animals, raises them and then sells them to butchers on profit.

Her husband belongs to an agriculture profession and works in the fields. He grows different seasonal crops in them. He is a very hard worker and works almost 9-10 hours per day. Naseem has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah to help her husband in improving his business. With the loan, he will buy fertilizer and seeds to get better results from his fields. She hopes that her husband’s business will grow further and he will be able to increase his household income. She is a new loan applicant of Asasah and this is her first loan application. She hopes that it will be a profitable experience for her.

Note: “In the photo, the lady holding a book (called Asasah Passbook) is Naseem”.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer and seeds for agriculture business

loans.name: Sork

texts.en: Sork S. is a 43-year-old farmer who lives in Kampong Chhnang Province. She is married to Lim Kheng, age 48. This couple, who work together in the farming business, have four single children. One of them works as a sewing worker at the manufactory and has a proper salary every month. Sork S. will be adding her loan to her personal savings to buy a piece of her neighbor’s farmland. The land is near her house, which is in a good location for farming. She will rent out this land to farmers for a fee. The loan will provide her with an additional new asset.

loans.use: to buy a piece of her neighbor’s farmland.

loans.name: Lilian Aloo

texts.en:
Lilian is 41 years old, married to Paul Wanganui and together they have five children, between 5 and 18 years old. She has been in the tailoring business for the last 20 years, and earns a profit margin of 8,000 Kenyan shillings. Lilian is on her first loan from KADET, which she will use to expand her business by purchasing more stock like fabrics and thread.

Lilian intends to plough the profits back into the business and educate her children. She dreams of expanding her business by opening other branches and educating her children up to university level.

loans.use: to purchase more stock, i.e. fabrics and thread.

loans.name: Flora

texts.en:
Flora A. is from the village of Bayabo, Tumuini, Isabela. She is 40 years old. Flora is married and has 2 school-aged children. To make a living, Flora owns and operates a business venture in the retail sector running a general store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling a variety of different products in the local community. Flora has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2007, Flora joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Flora has successfully repaid a previous loan of 23,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase baby livestock to raise and sell in future. Flora is requesting a new loan of 24000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional groceries to sell. This loan will be the 8th loan taken out by Flora from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand the borrower's business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional groceries to sell

loans.name: Patrick

texts.en:
Patrick K. is a married man. His wife stays at home to take care of the household chores. They have four grown up children. Patrick's business is located at Kongowea market in Mombasa, Kenya. Mombasa is the coastal region of Kenya and is well known for its many many tourist attraction sites including the white beaches on the Indian ocean. 

Patrick owns a grocery store in which he sells such items as onions, cabbages, mangoes, coconuts and bananas among other fruits to the local people. He has been in this business for the last ten years. He says that this business is profitable and that the major challenge he has is the high perishability of the food items he sells. However, he works very hard to keep his business doing well. He is using his loan of Kes 20,000 to buy stock of fruits and vegetables to expand his business. He hopes to own his own farm where he will be growing vegetables himself instead of buying to resell. He describes himself as very ambitious.

loans.use: to buy onions, cabbage, coconuts, bananas, etc.

loans.name: Khvay

texts.en:
Khvay B., 59, is a low-income person living in Kompong Tom Province. She is a good and determined single mother, divorced from her husband, who is trying to feed two children. She has one married child who lives separately, while the others are staying in the family home and working in a variety of jobs.

Khvay B. sells fresh fish in the market to earn a living. Every day in the late morning, she goes to a place where fishermen sell fish in bulk. Then she hurries to bring the fish to the market, where she sells them retail.

Recently, the family's living conditions have not been comfortable because their lavatory is broken. Thus, Khvay B. will use her loan to build a restroom for her family's use and to ensure proper sanitation.

loans.use: to build a restroom for her family

loans.name: Nancy

texts.en:
Nancy N., aged 48, is a single mother of two children, Evelyn, aged 19 and in college, and Selmith, aged 16, in high school. She runs a quarry stone business as her primary business located at Lukenya quarry site. Her business of three years gives her a monthly profit of Kshs 10,000.

She was introduced to KADET by the credit officer in charge of the Kitengela office. This is her first loan with KADET LTD and she plans to use it to purchase quarry equipment and tools such as a cutting machine.

She hopes to get good returns which she will use to buy another quarry space. Nancy describes herself as hard-working and ambitious.

loans.use: To purchase quarry equipment and tools such as a cutting machine.

loans.name: Arzykan

texts.en:
Arzykan C. is 62 and married. She has two children. She has higher education in economics and worked in the area of trading for a long time.  After retiring on pension, Arzykan decided to start her own business in cattle breeding. She has been engaged in this activity for the last two years and has reached success. Now her business, which was started with the initial capital of 50,000 KGS, consists of four cows and thirty eight sheep at the farm. Her monthly profit is about 3,000 – 4,000 KGS which allows her to broaden her business.

Arzykan wants to take a loan of 100,000 KGS to purchase one colt, two calves and sheep. With the revenues, she plans to develop her farm.


Bai-Tushum and Partners uses Kiva funding to target the especially vulnerable population. Bai-Tushum and Partners is one of the leading microfinance Institutions in Kyrgyzstan. As a reliable financial partner, Bai-Tushum contributes to the economic development of the Kyrgyz Republic through the delivery of microfinance services in rural and urban areas that lead to increased employment and meet the interests of its clients and investors.

loans.use: to purchase cattle

loans.name: Frengki

texts.en:
Frengky is a 42-year-old man who is married to Thersiana. They have three children - Meksi, Putra, and Daniel. Meksi is 15 years old and is in the 3rd grade of Junior high school. Putra is 10 years old and is in the 2nd grade of Elementary school. Daniel is 5 years old and is not at school yet. Frangky and family live in the village of Pariti, which is about 35 km from the Kupang City. 

In order to meet his family's needs, Frengky runs a shrimp business. Usually he goes to sea in the afternoon around 2 pm when the weather is good and returns home at 2 am in the following day. Frengky usually uses a trawl for catching the shrimp. In a day, Frengky can drag about 2 to 3 kg of shrimp, and he sells the shrimp at about IDR 35,000 to 55,000 per kg. However, his trawl is currently broken and Frengky does not have enough money to mend it. As a result, he cannot go to catch shrimp.

Frengky tried to farm in addition to catch shrimp. He planted cabbage in a small quantity due to the limited fund that he had. Of 100 seedlings of cabbage planted, 60 of them grow and can be harvested after 3 weeks. One cabbage is sold at IDR 4,000 at the traditional market in Camplong. Frengky sees that the result of farming cabbage is quite promising for the future and so he intends to seek for a loan to support him improving the businesses.

Frengky is requesting a loan amounting to IDR 10,000,000 from TLM. He plans to spend the loan on cabbage seeds, to fix the trawl and to buy a chainsaw to be leased. If the capital is still sufficient then he also plans to buy piglets for breeding. He really expects the loan can improve his family life in the future.

loans.use: to fix fishing equipment and buy cabbage seeds

loans.name: Elia Group

texts.fr: Lwanda M.  est entrepreneur, leader du groupe d’affaire Elia, âgée de 39 ans, femme vivant seule, mère de 3 enfants dont  2 étudient et l’autre a volontairement quitté le rang scolaire pour ses raisons personnelles. La  cliente  Lwanda M.  est vendeuse des pagnes (habits dames africaines). Elle expose ses marchandises au marché central de Virunga.il ya 20 ans qu’elle exerce cette activité. Elle démarra son activité avec un fonds propre reçu d’un membre de sa famille. Vers 2009, elle bénéficia de premier crédit de l’IMF Hekima pour  renforcer  son capital. Ce nouveau crédit doit lui servir de s’approvisionner  avec  des nouvelles marchandises des habits dames (20 pièces de pagnes).  En plus, elle ambitionne agrandir son entreprise. Selon elle, le crédit de Hekima lui a servi d’améliorer sa maison  et de vivre dans des conditions de vie digne socialement acceptables. La cliente Lwanda M.  remercie l’IMF Hekima pour  ses actions dédiées aux pauvres femmes exclues de banque classique. Le groupe Elia est constitué de 29 membres.
texts.en: Lwanda M. is an entrepreneur, the leader of the business group Elia, 39 years old, a single woman, and the mother of 3 children, 2 of whom are in school, while the other voluntarily left the scholarly ranks for personal reasons.  The client Lwanda M. sells African print cloth (for African women's garments).  She displays her merchandise at the central market of Virunga.  She has run this business for 20 years.  She started her business with her own funds, received from a family member.  Around 2009, she received her first loan from the IMF Hekima in order to strengthen her capital.  This new loan will allow her to restock with new merchandise of women's clothing (20 lengths of African print cloth).  Moreover, she aspires to grow her business.  According to her, the Hekima loan will allow her to improve her home and to live in conditions deemed socially acceptable.  The client Lwanda M. thanks the IMF Hekima for its actions dedicated to the poor women excluded from classic banks.  The group Elia is made up of 29 members.

loans.use: to purchase 20 lengths of African print cloth

location.country: The Democratic Republic of the Congo

loans.name: Lelengi

texts.en:
Lelengi, 35 years old and married with five children, owns a small business selling various styles of clothes and shoes in her living place. In operation for one year, her enterprise employs three persons from her community as helpers, and her hours of operation are 6 am until 8 pm daily.

Lelengi has requested a loan from Kiva lenders via Vision Finance Company to expand her business by purchasing bales of clothes and shoes. The loan will allow her to attract more customers and thus earn more profits which will enable her to renovate her house and save money for the future.

loans.use: to increase her business.

loans.name: Beviena

texts.en:
Beviena M. is from the village of Bantuanon, Lantapan, Bukidnon. She is 52 years old. Beviena is married and has 6 adult children. To make a living, Beviena owns & operates a sari-sari (variety) shop selling products for daily use, such as shampoo, soap, canned goods, snack foods & beverages.  Beviena has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 9000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2011, Beviena joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Beviena is requesting a loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell, like breads & canned goods. This loan will be the 1st loan taken out by Beviena from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell, like breads & canned goods

loans.name: Phin

texts.en:
Phin S. is 47-year-old married woman and mother. She lives with other family members in her own small family home in Phnom Penh City. She owns a piece of land that she inherited from her grandmother. She grows different kinds of crops on her land, such as rice and morning glories, which she will sell to buyers every two or three months when the plants mature. 

Phin S. has a life partner in her husband who works in the construction field. The couple is married and has four kids; two are married and the other two are single and employed in different occupations.

 Phin S. is concerned that her house is small and narrow, and it is so hard for her and her family to live in. In order to deal with this issue, Phin S. would like to request a loan to add to her savings to build a new wooden house which will be bigger than at the present time.

loans.use: To build a new wooden house.

loans.name: Julita

texts.en:
Julita V. is from the village of Bayabo, Tumuini, Isabela. She is 43 years old. Julita is married and has 3 adult-aged children. To make a living, Julita owns & operates a business raising raising ducks for sale. Julita has been engaged in her business for over 20 years and earns approximately 6000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2007, Julita joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Julita has successfully repaid a previous loan of 15,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase baby livestock to raise & sell in the future. Julita is requesting a new loan of 17000 PHP, which will be used to purchase livestock feed and other supplies. This loan will be the 8th loan taken out by Julita from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase livestock feed and other supplies

loans.name: Regina

texts.en:
Regina G. is from the village of Bantuanon, Lantapan, Bukidnon. She is 58 years old. Regina is widowed and has one adult child. To make a living, Regina owns & operates a sari-sari (variety) shop selling products for daily use, such as shampoo, soap, and toothpaste, in the local community. Regina has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 10000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2011, Regina joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Regina is requesting a loan of 5000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell, like canned goods and snack foods. This loan will be the 1st loan taken out by Regina from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell, like canned goods & snack foods

loans.name: Afi

texts.fr: Dame Afi est mariée et  a 2 enfants  à charge. Elle est âgée de 30 ans et habite quartier Adamavo. Elle fait le commerce de pagnes pour participer au foyer. Aussi elle a parfaitement remboursé 2 crédits déjà. Elle achète  les pagnes au grand marché de Lomé en gros et redistribue en détail. Elle est ambulante et a commencé son activité  en 1996.  Elle demande un prêt pour se réapprovisionner.
texts.en: Dame Afi is married and has 2 children in her care.  She is 30 years old and lives in the Adamavo district.  She runs her African print cloth business to contribute to the household.  Also, she has already paid back 2 loans perfectly.  She buys her print cloth in bulk at the large market of Lomé and re-distributes it at retail.  She is a travelling saleswoman and began her business in 1996.  She is asking for a loan to restock.

loans.use: to purchase African print cloths

loans.name: Erni

texts.en:
Erni is a 27-year-old woman who lives in Oebufu village and is married to Alex, a 30 year old man.  They have three children:  5 year-old Indi, who is in kindergarten, and Inda and Intan, who are 4 and 3 years old.  

Emi, a woman who diligently attends family worship services, runs a billiard business. She purchased a secondhand billiard table and leases it to those who love to play this kind of sport. She has been running the billiard business for about three years. The condition of the billiard cloth is currently not good – it is scratched and it has an impact on her income. The income from her billiard business is currently between IDR 20,000 - 30,000 per day.  Her husband's income from the motor-taxi business is unstable. 

Erni also farms vegetables. The farm is situated close to her house. She grows vegetables in a small quantity as she only had a little money to buy seeds and fertilizer. When she heard about TLM Lending Programs, she thought about improving the farm with various vegetable seeds and sufficient fertilizer. She also plans to improve her billiard business by replacing the scratched billiard cloth. She is requesting a loan amounting of IDR 3,000,000 from TLM. She really hopes that the loan will help increase her income from her vegetables and billiard business.

loans.use: To buy billiard cloth for re-upholstery, and seeds for farming

loans.name: Rose

texts.en: Rose W. is a married lady who has one child, aged three years. Her business is located at Kongowea estate in Mombasa, Kenya.  Mombasa is in the coastal region of Kenya and is well known for its many tourist attraction sites, including the Indian Ocean's white beaches. She owns a beauty salon in which she sells hair weaves, relaxers and treatments, as well as taking care of women's hair. She has been in this business for the last three years and has managed to give employment to one person. She says that this business is profitable, and that the major challenge she has is debtors who refuse to pay as per agreement. However, she works very hard from early morning to late evening to keep her business doing well. She is using her loan of Kes 25,000 to buy salon equipment to expand her business. She sees herself becoming a beauty consultant inthe future. She describes herself as ambitious.

loans.use: to buy salon equipment

loans.name: Rowena

texts.en:
Rowena G. is from the village of Bayabo, Tumauini, Isabela. She is 43 years old. Rowena is married and has 3 adult children. To make a living, Rowena owns & operates a business selling fish products in the local community. Rowena has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 6,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2007, Rowena joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Rowena has successfully repaid a previous loan of 15,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Rowena is requesting a new loan of 20,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional raw ingredients to make more fish products for sale. This loan will be the 8th loan taken out by Rowena from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional raw ingredients to make more fish products for sale

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy new deep-frying pans for preparing "mandazi"s, tables for displaying the cooked mandazis and tablespoons.

loans.name: Midoakpéné

texts.fr: Madame  Midoakpénè a 32 ans et est mariée. Elle a un enfant. Pour contribuer au ménage, elle exerce comme activité la vente de produits d’alimentation générale. En effet elle achète ces produits  au  grand marché de Lomé  et revend  dans un magasin à Adidogomé non loin de Boukarou.  Elle sollicite un prêt  pour acheter 5 bidons d’huile, 3 cartons de savon BF, 4 sacs de sucre et 5 sacs de riz  Gino.
texts.en: Madame  Midoakpénè is 32 years old and married.  To contribute to the household, she runs a business selling general food products.  She buys her products at the large market of  Lomé  and resells them in a store in Adidogomé, not far from Boukarou.  She is asking for a loan to buy 5 drums of oil, 3 boxes of BF soap, 4 bags of sugar and 5 bags of Gino rice.

loans.use: to purchase food products

loans.name: Grace Wachuka

texts.en:
Grace has practised farming in Ndunyu, Njeru town for the last 4 years.  She is 36 years old, married to John Kerenge, and they have six children.  

She was introduced to KADET by her friend and this will be her third loan.  She repaid both her previous loans well and in good time.  She plans to use the loan amount to buy another dairy cow.

In future, Grace hopes to grow her dairy farm and become a leading supplier of dairy products in Ndunyu, Njeru town.

loans.use: To buy a dairy cow.

loans.name: Marites

texts.en:
Marites P. is from the village of Bayabo, Tumuini, Isabela. She is 39 years old. Marites is married and has 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Marites owns & operates a business preparing and selling cooked food for daily meals. Marites has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 3500 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2007, Marites joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Marites has successfully repaid a previous loan of 12,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell.  Marites is requesting a new loan of 15000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional raw ingredients to cook more dishes to sell. This loan will be the 8th loan taken out by Marites from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional raw ingredients to cook more dishes to sell

loans.name: Khun

texts.en:
Khun S. is a 28-year-old woman who earns a living as an employee at the garment industry as a worker. She has been working in her job for a few years and has a formal salary. She is married but she has been divorced from her husband since her child was young. 

Khun S. says that she has a problem traveling to her workplace. She always travels to work by hiring a taxi as she doesn’t have her own vehicle. To solve the trouble, Khun S. has requested a loan in the amount of $1200 to be used to buy a new motorcycle to provide transportation without hiring a taxi.

loans.use: To buy a new motorcycle to ride to her job location.

loans.name: Silas Odoyo

texts.en:
Silas O. is a 30-year-old gentleman. He and his wife Pamela have five children. They live in Migori, Kenya.

Silas is a carpenter, and he has been in business for one year. He is applying for his first loan from KADET after being introduced to the organization by a friend. He intends to use the loan to buy more timber. He already has some orders from customers, and the loan will really help him to meet their demands.

Silas hopes to expand his business and use the profits made to educate his children.

loans.use: to buy timber

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy three bulls to add to his stock

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy sugar to add to his stock

loans.name: Willy

texts.en:
Willy has a mixed farm in Kitale town, western Kenya, that produces milk, maize and beans. He has been in the farming business for fifteen years now and employs one farmhand. He also runs a retail shop in the same region.

He has requested for a loan of 62,400 Kes through Juhudi Kilimo to purchase and insure a dairy cow. The extra income from this loan will enable him to expand his existing businesses and also meet his family's needs. He plans to acquire a high yield dairy cow and also venture into zero grazing in the next 5 years.

Willy is 35 years old and married, with 3 children aged between 8 months and 9 years.

loans.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow.

loans.name: Ruth

texts.en:
Ruth I. is 37 years old and is married to Gilbert. They have three children and live in Mbale town.

Ruth has a business of selling second-hand clothes and has been in this business for the past ten years. She earns a monthly income of Kshs 13,200. She is applying for her first loan from KADET LTD after being introduced by a friend who is a client here. Ruth wants to buy more clothes to add to her stock, which is running low. She hopes to use the profits made from the business to pay school fees for her children and to cover her family's needs.

Her dream is to see her business grow to great heights.

loans.use: to buy more clothes to add to her stock

loans.name: Annah Muthoni

texts.en:
Annah has practiced farming in Ndunyu Njeru town for the last 17 years.  She is 48 years old and married to Francis Mbugua. They have five children.  

She was introduced to KADET by her friend.  This will be Annah's third loan; she paid all her previous loans on time.  She plans to use the loan to buy seeds and fertilizers for farming.

In the future, Annah hopes to buy more land and practice large-scale farming.

loans.use: to buy seeds and fertilizer for farming

loans.name: Martin

texts.en:
Martin is 51 years old and is married, with three children who are between 6 and 20 years old. Martin takes care of one dependent who is a 20 year-old relative. He and his wife work hard for the development of their family. 

Martin owns a business selling cassava.  His business is well-known, as well as organized. He employs three people as helpers so that his business runs smoothly. Martin has four years experience in his business.  The hours of his business are from 6am until 9pm every day.

Martin has requested his first loan from KIva lenders, via Vision Finance Company, in order to purchase more cassava.  That will help him to satisfy his many customers of cassava.  Martin will then be able to earn more profits to be reinvested in his business, and will save money for his future.

loans.use: To purchase more large quanties of cassava.

loans.name: Sèdégbédo Group

texts.en:
The Sèdégbédo Group consists of three women who live in the same building, and who used to lend each other money before their involvement with micro-credit through ALIDE. They now support each other in their businesses and in repayments. This is the fourth loan the group has sought from ALIDE following successful repayments in the past.

Rène (with her hand raised in the photo) was born in 1978 and has spent the past 27 years living in Allada, a small town north of the capital, in a rural region. Uneducated, she lives with her husband Brice, their four children, and three further relations to support.

Nine years ago Rène opened her stall to produce and sell cheese and sauce at the main market in town. To supplement her income she has begun also selling palm tree nuts. It is to expand this second product line that Rène is seeking a loan from ALIDE.

Her aim is to extend her credit eligibility through good repayments so that she may extend her business and cover all her family's needs. She cites her personal strengths as tenacity and respect of commitments.

loans.use: to purchase palm nuts for resale

loans.name: Azra's Group

texts.en:
Azra lives in Khanewal, which is a small city located in Punjab province of Pakistan and known for its agriculture industry. She has been living there in a 2 room brick house with her family in the area of Shanti nagar for the past 10 years. She is 48 years old, married to A., and the mother of 3 children. All of them are enrolled in a local school. Azra is a caring lady who stays at home and carries out her responsibilities of a housewife very well. 

She has applied for a loan from Kiva partner, Asasah, for her husband’s grocery business. He runs his grocery store in the market where he sells items of daily use to his customers.  With the loan, she will buy items such as cooking oil, salt, lentils, rice and sugar, etc., to sell at his shop. Azra hopes that an investment will be a productive one for him. 
She is a regular loan user of Asasah. This is her 3rd loan application. In previous loan years, she has maintained a good credit behavior and never missed any meeting. 
Note: “In the photo, the lady holding a book (called Asasah Passbook) is Azra”.

loans.use: To buy groceries for store

loans.name: Bon Pasteur Group

texts.en:
The Bon Pasteur group consists of four women who attend the same church in Porto-Novo, Benin's administrative capital. This is their third loan with ALIDE, following successful repayment of past loans. As a group they have agreed to support each other in business and in loan repayments.

Marguérite (with her hand raised in the photo) has lived in Porto-Novo since birth nearly 40 years ago. Five years ago she moved to a new district with her husband and two children. Both parents support their children, who were educated through school.

From her shop Marguérite sells various products - mainly dressmaking supplies - but she is also expanding to soaps and charcoal sales. It is to fund this product expansion that she has asked for a loan, with her long term ambition of building a house. Marguérite believes her strengths lie in her liveliness, her welcome, and her faith.

loans.use: to purchase more stock of cloth and supplies

loans.name: Djromahuton Senadé Group

texts.en:
The Djromahuton Senadé Group consists of nine women who are all in the same product sales. They have agreed to support each other in business and in loan repayments, and this is the first loan they are taking from ALIDE.

Séraphine is the leader of the group (pictured with her hand raised), and was born in 1969 in Cotonou, Benin's largest city and economic center. She is married with three children, all of whom are schooled. For the last three years she has run a stall selling household products in front of the local town hall. She will use this loan to purchase additional goods from Chinese importers, for her to resell at her stall. Her long term aim is to expand her business and support a larger product line.

She believes her dynamism is her strong point as a saleswoman.

loans.use: to purchase Chinese imports to resell

loans.name: Zacharia

texts.en:
Zacharia, 30, is a dairy farmer from Kitale town in Western Kenya. He is married with four children aged between 2 and 7 years. He has been doing mixed farming for two years and selling his milk to the local market. He has employed one farmhand. He gets additional income from temporary employment in a local secondary school.

Zacharia has requested a loan of 31,200 KES from Juhudi Kilimo to purchase and insure a dairy cow. He says he will use the income generated from this loan to pay for the education of his children. He is also focusing on owning five dairy cows in the future.

Zacharia laments that animal feeds have become very expensive due to scarcity.

loans.use: to purchase and insure a dairy cow

loans.name: Missimide 2 Group

texts.en:
The Missimide group consists of 10 women who live in the same village outside of Porto-Novo, Benin's administrative capital. They have agreed to support each other in business and loan repayments, and this is their fifth loan from ALIDE.

Clémentine is the leader of the group (with her hand raised in the photo). She is married to Pascal, a harvester. Together they have four children, two of whom are still with their parents. All children are schooled.

For the last ten years Clémentine has worked in processing the nuts from palm trees into pulp to be used for various foods. She also sells crockery from her stall. With this loan she will purchase more raw material for processing, as well as further crockery items for resale. In the long term she hopes to expand her business and be able to purchase a processing machine to increase capacity.

As her strongest attributes in business, Clémentine cites her dynamic and welcoming personality.

loans.use: to purchase palm tree nuts for processing

loans.name: Shakirah

texts.en:
Shakirah N. is 18 years old and lives in the town of Kalerwe in the Kampala central region of Uganda.  She is single and has no children.  Shakirah has a business of selling tap water, which she has had for 3 years.

To help expand her business, Shakirah has requested a loan of 400,000 Ugandan shillings from BRAC Uganda.  The loan will be used to purchase and pay for the water bills.  With the help of this loan from BRAC, Shakirah hopes to generate greater profits and pay school fees for herself and also buy food for home.  In the future, Shakirah hopes to take a course in mass communication.  Shakirah is a member of BRAC’s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program, which has helped her prospects for the future by improving her business so that she can pay for her school fees.

loans.use: to purchase and pay for the water.

loans.name: Alex

texts.en:
Alex, 24, is a father of 5-year-old twin children who both attend school. He has been practicing mixed farming for over two years in his hometown of Kitale in Western Kenya. He sells his milk product to a wholesale dealer in the local market. 

Alex has requested a loan of 30,000 KES for poultry farming. He wants to save the income generated specifically for the education of his children, whom he regards as special. He also wants to own a pick-up in the future that will assist in transportation of milk to the market.

Alex is full of appreciation for Juhudi Kilimo's loan services. However, he laments it is costly to maintain the animals due to rampant diseases.

loans.use: to assist in poultry farming

loans.name: Shamilah

texts.en:
Shamilah N. is 20 years old and lives in the town of Kalerwe in the Kampala central region of Uganda.  She is single and has no children.  Shamilah has a business of tailoring, which she has had for three years.

To help expand her business, Shamilah has requested a loan of 200,000 Ugandan shillings from BRAC Uganda.  The loan will be used to purchase materials for making clothes for resale.  With the help of this loan from BRAC, Shamilah hopes to generate greater profits and pay school fees for herself.  In the future, Shamilah hopes to buy another tailoring machine.  

Shamilah is a member of BRAC’s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program, which has helped her prospects for the future by helping her to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase materials for making clothes for resale.

loans.name: Angela

texts.en:
Angela N. is 20 years old and lives in the town of Kalerwe in the Kampala central region of Uganda.  She is single and has no children.  Angela has a business of selling clothes, which she has had for three years.  She also has a second business of selling shoes.  

To help expand her business, Angela has requested a loan of 150,000 Ugandan shillings from BRAC Uganda.  The loan will be used to purchase more clothes for resale.  With the help of this loan from BRAC, Angela hopes to generate greater profits and take care of herself.  In the future, Angela hopes to become a popular singer.   

Angela is a member of BRAC’s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program which has helped her prospects for the future by helping her get more capital from her business than before.

loans.use: to purchase more clothes for resale.

loans.name: Sarah

texts.en:
Sarah N. is 22 years old and lives in the town of Kalerwe in the Kampala central region of Uganda.  She is married and has three children.  Two of her children are currently in school.  Sarah has a cosmetic shop selling all types of body lotion, which she has had for two years.  She also has a second business of selling shoes.  

To help expand her business, Sarah has requested a loan of 300,000 Ugandan shillings from BRAC Uganda.  The loan will be used to purchase more cosmetic lotions and shoes for resale.  With the help of this loan from BRAC, Sarah hopes to generate greater profits and contribute to paying school fees.  In the future, Sarah hopes to expand her business and also build a house. 

Sarah is a member of BRAC’s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program, which has helped her prospects for the future by allowing her to become self-reliant.

loans.use: to purchase more cosmetic lotions and shoes for resale.

loans.name: Carolyne

texts.en:
Carolyne K. is 28 years old and married to Edward. They have two children. 

Carolyne has a business of selling second-hand clothes and has been running her business for the past four years. Her monthly income is Kshs 12,900. She is applying for her first loan from KADET LTD after being introduced by a friend who is also a client. She intends to use the money to buy more clothes to add to her business. She plans to use the profits to pay school fees for her children.

She hopes to expand her business greatly in the future.

loans.use: to buy more clothes to add to her stock

loans.name: Chea

texts.en: Mrs. Chea S.,age 39, married woman who has one small house, Reussey Keo commune,in Phnom Penh city. Presently, she always goes to her homeland a farmland , where border to Phnom Penh and Kampong Speu, to plant the different of her corps on her farmland which comes from her grandparent for many years. In addition, she also sells small rocks (she breaks the big rock from the mountain into small pieces and then selling). She and her husband depend on income from their farming business, whose core activity is cultivating various vegetable and fruit crops for harvest and sale to buyers. Because of a lack of money, Mrs. Chea S. doesn’t have enough capital to grow her crop-planting business, so she would like to ask for a loan of $700 USD. She will use part of the loan to buy watermelon seeds for growing in the second step and the remainder to dig a well for her family's use. The couple is blessed with two children who are going to school.

loans.use: To buy watermelon seeds for growing in the second step and dig a well for her family's use.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to construct a new pub

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to stock a beauty shop

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy chickens for poultry farming.

loans.name: Hevi

texts.en:
Hevi is a 46 year-old woman who is married to Adrian, 54. They have two children.  Marco, 23 years old, is a student at a university in Kupang, and is in his 8th semester.  Cherri is 21 years old and is a student at a university in Malang (Java Island) where she is in her 6th semester. 

Hevi has a shop in Tuak Daun Merah village. She has been operating her shop for 8 months, so she does not have a great variety of products. She wishes to add more goods. The unavailability of some products required by her customers has disappointed them. For example, most of her customers are women and children who are looking for cosmetic products, such as powder, lipstick, etc., as well as snacks for children.  In a day, she can earn roughly IDR 90,000 - 150,000.  She has to manage her income well, as she has to meet her children's education needs at the university, especially for Cherri, who is living on a different island.

Hevi is requesting a loan of IDR 4,500,000 from TLM. She will use the money to buy cosmetic products, such as powder, lipstick, etc., as well as various snacks and bread to be sold.

loans.use: To buy cosmetic products and various snacks

loans.name: Sapargul's Group

texts.ru:
Сапаргуль Вахапова, 35 лет, лидер этой группы, полна энергичности и мотивации чтобы усовершенствовать свой бизнес, фундамент которого был проложен 12 лет тому назад. Связав семейные узы Сапаргуль и ее супруг, как и большинство узгенских семей сделали первые скромные шаги в животноводстве. Тогда Сапаргуль даже не догадывалась, что 5000 сомов стартового капитала будут пожалуй самым выгодным вложением в ее карьере. Животноводство всегда было социально важным занятием для местных поселений наряду с земледелием и торговлей. Уже в раннем детстве Сапаргуль со сверстниками отправлялась пасти скот на пастбища с обилием свежей травы и родниковой воды. Да и сейчас наша клиентка очень ответственно подходит к вопросу о корме и условиях содержания скота. Она проводит регулярный осмотр скота у ветеринара, так как ее товар напрямую влияет на состояние здоровья потребителя. А для Сапаргуль удовлетворенность покупателей – это самое главное, так как это залог дальнейшего спроса. Но тучи сгустились над этим бизнесом в последние годы. Повышенные расходы стали понижать прибыль от бизнеса, а попытка ощутимо повысить цены на живность вызывала негодование у потребителей. Дошло до того, что месячная прибыль опустилась до отметки в 2 000 сомов, что было недостаточно даже чтобы обеспечить ежедневные нужды двоих детей, семиклассницы Акбермет и трехлетнего Эмира. Пожалуй это было последним толчком в сознании Сапаргуль и она решилась попробовать параллельно заниматься земледелием. В Узгене очень благоприятные условия для этого дела. Именно эта идея подтолкнула Сапаргуль к образованию группы, для получения кредита от Кивы. Конкретной целью кредита является закупка удобрений для весенней подготовки земли. 
       
--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 
								
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.
texts.en: Sapargul V., 35 years old, is this group’s leader. She is full of energy and motivation to improve her business, which had been founded 12 years ago. After tying the marriage knot, Sapargul and her husband, like most families in Uzgen, took their first small steps in starting a livestock business. Back then, Sapargul could never have guessed that 5000 soms of starting capital would turn out to be possibly the best investment in all her career. Raising livestock always has been socially important for the local population, along with farming and trade. Already as a young girl, Sapargul would go together with her friends to guard farm animals at grazing fields with plenty of fresh grass and spring water. And now our client still takes the issue of nutrition and other living conditions of her livestock very responsibly. She has her animals regularly examined by  a veterinarian, since the products she sells have a direct impact on consumers’ health. In recent years, however, storm clouds have gathered over this business. An increase in expenditures led to a reduced business revenue, and the attempt to raise prices in a perceptible way has been met with anger by the consumers. It had come to the point that their monthly income fell all the way down to 2,000 soms, which was insufficient even to provide for the day-to-day needs of their two children: their daughter Akhbermet, who is in 7th grade, and their 3-year old son Emir. This was the last drop for Sapargul, and she decided to also go into agriculture as a parallel activity. Uzgen offers auspicious conditions for agriculture. This idea led Sparagul to forming a group in order to take out a loan from Kiva. The concrete purpose of this loan is purchasing fertilizer to prepare soil in the spring.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To build a modern poultry unit

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To build a new fence.

loans.name: Uruila's Group

texts.en:
The leader of this group, Uruila C., 46, is a proud mother of three boys, the youngest of whom is 19 years old. Uruila is a well-experienced farmer who works the entire spring, summer and fall, knowing from her life experience that earning money is not easy. Although farming offers a steady source of income because food is always in demand, it also carries risks due to weather conditions or factors such as the economic or political situation of the country.

Uruila has been farming for 10 years in a town in Uzgen in southern Kyrgyzstan. Her major crops are sunflower seeds and a special type of Uzgen rice unique to this region and requiring special care. Uruila is thankful to live in such a productive area and earns a monthly income of about 16 000 soms. But Uruila is sure that her energy will help her do more if she is able to achieve additional financial support, and so is requesting this loan in order to purchase 100 kg of seeds and 300 kg of fertilizers. She hopes to achieve a rich harvest in the fall because she will use the best fertilizers.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year.

To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers

loans.name: Devotha

texts.en:
Devotha is 41 years old and is married, with one child who is four years old. Devotha owns a small business selling various styles of clothes for men and women. This business is known and organized. The hours of her business are from 7am until 8pm every day.

Devotha has requested her first loan from Kiva lenders, via Vision Finance Company, in order to expand her business through purchasing bales of clothes. Once this expansion is reached, Devotha will be able to earn more profit. With this profit, she will build her own house and reinvest in her business.

loans.use: To purchase more clothes.

loans.name: Faxraddin

texts.ru:
Faxraddin G. rodilsya v 1963. On jenat i imeyet 1 rebonka. Faxraddin yavlyayetsya IDP personom on pereselenec iz Fuzuli qoroda i seychas projivayet v Fuzuli regione vmeste so svoyey jenoy i rebonkom. On uje 7 let kak rabotayet taksistom. 
Seychas on nujdayetsya v 2000 AZN chtobi kupit nujniye zapchasti dlya pochinki svoyey mashini , Tak kak yeqo mahsina isportilas, seychas on ne mojet razvozit kliyentov poeotmu on nujdayetsya v pochinke mashini.
texts.en: Faxraddin G. was born in 1963. He is married and has one child. Faxraddin is an Internally Displaced Person from the town of Fuzuli, now living in Fuzuli Region together with his wife and child. He has been working as a taxi driver for the past seven years. At present he needs 2000 AZN in order to buy spare parts to repair his car. Since his car broke down, he is now unable to transport client, and this is why he needs to have his car repaired.

loans.use: to buy spare parts for his car

loans.name: Madina's Group

texts.ru:
Кыргызская пословица гласит «Скажи мне кто твой друг и я скажу кто ты». Эта пословица вполне применима к группе предпринимателей, возглавляемой Мадиной Махматовой, так как их объединяет долгая сильная дружба и общая целенаправленность. Мадина, 34хлетняя роженица города Узген на солнечном юге Кыргызстана, супруга фермера и мать троих сыновей. Всю жизнь Мадина прожила в это солнечном городе и сельское хозяйство всегда было доминирующим по масштабам привлечения населения и прибыльности. Уже 14 лет Мадина и ее супруг вовлечены в выращивание сельскохозяйственной продукции, начиная от мелкой зелени до высокосортного узгенского риса ,известного своим уникальным вкусом. После напряженной работы весной и летом наступает щедрая для фермеров осень. Узгенская плодородная почва и теплый климат приносят богатый урожай. Одной такой осенью доход семьи Мадины позволил приобрести небольшой земельный участок и построить дом. Скоро начнутся посевные работы и весь цикл начнется заново. Чтобы получить хороший урожай необходимо как следует ухаживать за землей. Удобрения на такой большой земельный участок могут обойтись в большую сумму. С этой целью Мадина обратилась за финансовой поддержкой в Киву. В будущем она желает воспитать детей и улучшить благосостояние семьи. 


--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 
								
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.
texts.en:
There's one Kyrgyz saying which says "Tell me who is your friend and I will tell you who you are." This saying is very applicable to the group of entrepreneurs headed by Madina M. because they are united for a strong friendship and mutual purposefulness.

Madina is 34 years old, she was born in the town of Uzgen in the sunny south of Kyrgyztan, a wife of a farmer and a mother of three sons. Madina lived all her life in this sunny city and agriculture has been dominant in attracting the residents and profits. For fourteen years Madina and her husband were involved in growing agriculture products from small greens and to tall Uzgen rice which is famous for it's unique taste. After the hard work in the spring and summer comes the bountiful for the farmers autumn. The fertile land of Uzgen and its warm climate bring a rich harvest. During one of these autumns the income of Madina's family had allowed them to buy a small plot of land and to build a house.

Soon the sowing season will begin and the cycle will begin again. To collect a good harvest taking good care of the land is a must. The fertilizer for such a big area of land can be very costly. Madina has asked for financial assistance from Kiva with this purpose. In the future she wants to raise her children and improve the well being of her family.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer

loans.name: Houénoussou Group

texts.en:
The Houénoussou group consists of thirteen women who all live in the same village and who met each other through one of the group. This is the second loan they are taking from ALIDE, following the successful repayment of their first loan. The group has agreed to support each other through loan repayments.

Micheline was born in 1959, and now lives in Allada, a rural town inland from Benin. She and her husband Féverin have six children, three of whom still live at home. For the past nine years Micheline has sold charcoal that she sources from a village nearby in the market at Allada. With this loan she hopes to purchase ten bags of charcoal as additional stock. Her aim is to grow her sales while providing for her three children still at home. Her strengths are her dynamism and adaptability.

loans.use: to purchase charcoal for resale

loans.name: Jesutin Group

texts.en:
The Jesutin group consists of fifteen women who live in the same district on the outskirts of Cotonou, Benin's economic center. They normally meet once a week to offer support in business and for loan repayments. This is their first loan with ALIDE.

Ablawa is nearly thirty years old, and lives with her husband Julien and their three children who are all schooled. For the past ten years she has sold products as a traveling saleswoman, particularly within the Pahou market. She currently sells plastic items such as washing bowls and buckets, as well as soap. 

With her loan she hopes to purchase three dozen plastic buckets and six crates of soap from Tokpa, Benin's largest market. Her ambition is to have her own stall at the market, and grow her business from there.

loans.use: to purchase plastic bowls and buckets, as well as soap, for resale

loans.name: Anarhan's Group

texts.ru:
В 1994 году, три года после распада Советского союза и начала перестройки, семья Назаркуловых была наделена земельным участком в несколько гектаров. Привыкшие работать на коллективное благо, для Назаркуловых было новшеством начать свой личный бизнес. Анархан Назаркулова, 53 летний лидер этой группы, первой по инициативе своего мужа купила на 2 000 сомов скот для разведения. Так как земледелие – это сезонный источник дохода, животноводство оказалось хорошим дополнением в копилку семьи. Зимнее время – это перерыв для земледела , но у Анархан теперь есть новые заботы о живности. Особенно в зимнее время живность требует особого ухода в отличии от лета, когда скот может ,позаботиться о себе». Супруг Анархан – гидротехник, и у них 15летняя дочь, финансово зависящая о них. Старший 25летнй сын работает в ташкумырском ГАО и в тоже вносит свою лепту в развитие семейного бизнеса. 15летний стаж оправдал ожидания Анархан. На данный момент сельское хозяйство совместно с откормом и разведением скота приносят Анархан около 9 500 сомов месячного дохода. Как и все фермеры, Анархан с нетерпением ждет начала посевов. Покупка удобрений будет ее основной затратой, поэтому она  хочет получить кредит. 


--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan.
